April 01, 2014JD Rennison

YouTube broadcaster sued by computer games company

A YouTube commentator who reviews computer and mobile games has found himself at the end of a lawsuit by a video game corporation.

Daniel Hardcastle, commonly known by his alias NerdCubed, posted a YouTube review of a mobile-based puzzle game published by retail giant EA last January where he made remarks on the state of mobile game purchases today.

EA has created a version of game Dungeon Keeper which is free to download and play but requires the user to make purchases within the game in order to unlock certain features which according to Mr. Hardcastle are required to lift some artificially imposed delays during gameplay that hamper user experience.

"The game has received five starts from thousands of people who I'm assuming are all complete and total fuckwits", "If anyone pays for that you're just a fucking idiot" and "I didn't know there are cunts like EA trying to charge that much money for fuck all" seemed to be some of Hardcastle's comments that sparked the legal action.

"This is a smear campaign", said an EA spokesperson. "If our practices were unethical or illegal there would have been arrests of some board members. No one has been arrested. In fact Dungeon Keeper has been received well by mobile users. Not everyone may like the game, of course, but those who don't simply do not download it. For most people it ends there but not for Mr. Hardcastle."

"Also, we have lost 0.6% in earnings since the video was published. We are holding Mr. Hardcastle entirely responsible."

"Then we'll come for Jim Sterling from the Escapist."

March 22, 2014JD Rennison

Everyone was looking away and no one stepped in to help

Twitter can be utter shit yet other times can be a good source of information about what's happening in your city.

I was recently reading the feed of editor Fiona Mountford who claims she got pushed and verbally abused on the tube.

What did everyone else on the carriage did to defend the lady in distress?

Man offers to fight me on platform of next station. I kindly decline offer. All men in carriage resolutely avoid my gaze.

— Fiona Mountford (@FionaLondonarts) March 13, 2014

So, once again, a big thank you to all the men in the carriage, who did nothing while I was being threatened. Genuine thanks to kind ladies.

— Fiona Mountford (@FionaLondonarts) March 13, 2014

Damn those men who let her be abused and did nothing to intervene. If I were there I would be the first to jump up from my seat and say (doing a Jason Statham voice) "the lady said to leave her alone". Seriously, of all the men on the carriage no one stood up for her?

Oh. Right.

Even if you are some spec-ops veteran or a martial arts expert and could take him, we live in a society where if you're not paid handle such incidents, the cops won't take kindly to you getting involved in a potential fight. Be that as it may, even people who are trained to knock out others with bare hands cannot know the outcome of a fight beforehand and could still be sent to hospital. Not defending themselves or a loved one but a complete stranger. Most people (men included) are not trained fighters.

I wouldn't intervene if a stranger was getting beaten because:
1. You could get harmed or killed when you could just not have provoked the assailant. Someone else was the object of their wrath. C'est la vie. The two links above are an example of what could happen.
2. You become the new target giving the original target the opportunity to scarper. Would the original target join back the fight?
3. We live in a society where this can get you arrested if you're not trained and appointed by the state to break up fights. When you are arrested:

  • You have to find and pay for a good solicitor
  • You have to take time off work
  • You, your friends and family are put through trauma for days, weeks or months.
  • If you're not trained and manage subdue the assailant you don't know what amount of force could be regarded reasonable by the police and if they think you used excessive force you could be charged.

All this not when you've done something wrong but something very right.

At least this is what the media says can happen and just who am I to dispute a story saying "Man held by police for defending his home from burglars".

Would you like to have one or more of these happen to you over an incident involving a total stranger? I wouldn't. As an eye witness I'd give a statement to the police when they arrived on scene but never intervene.

Μany years ago on the train. Two girls sit together, one of them is chatting loudly on the phone. A woman nearby tells her off.

"Aw I didn't realize I'm disturbin' you innit. I talk on the phone and get told off innit. Bloody 'ell no one else's complainin'".

No, she didn't assault the other woman but simply got up and moved further down the train, yet she had taken a risk for challenging the two chavs. If someone is so inconsiderate that talks loudly on the phone on the train, I tend to assume he won't take too kindly to getting told off by a stranger. With all these knife-wielding thugs ridding London you have to assume the worst. After all you're just going to work and you don't want to swing by the hospital on the way there, getting treated for stab wounds. Over two chavs being chavs. Although I'm pretty sure I've picked up a few STDs just by being on the same carriage with them that morning.

I said something to the other woman though: If she was attacked no one would come to her rescue and that's something to think about next time she thinks about doing what everyone else is thinking. She said she would still do the same thing.

And, anyway, all of us who came to live in London later in life and in the first few months tried to help a complete stranger we'd get rejected until we gave up. The proof for this is that I say so.

I've written a few lines of code that illustrates caring for a stranger in a big city:

$a = some bad shit that may happen to people while walking on the street.
$x = guy who gets $a
$y = guy who gets paid to take care of people that get $a
$me = !($x || $y)
So $me can fuck off about $me's god-damn business.

Just to respond to any allegation of sexism that may arise from the use of the word "guy" in the above source code. I used "guy" instead of "person" because suck my todger, that's why.

February 27, 2014JD Rennison

Disappearance

"When was the last time you saw Mr. David Anderson?" asked the Met detective.
"Well, he came to the office two days ago, went on his lunch break and never came back." said the director.
"His wife called the office the next day and when we told her he's not come back since last afternoon she said she would call the police"
"I see. What is the position held by Mr. Anderson in your company?"
"He is an IT project manager. He manages the timescales and the delivery of our technology projects".
"That's all I needed to ask. If anything turns up will you call me on this number please."
"Of course. Oh there's something else which I don't know if it matters much but I think I should tell you anyway. The last thing he said before he disappeared was to one of the guys in the development team. I overheard him because I happened to be walking by at the time."
"He said. 'It can't be a big job can it? We are already doing this in another part of the codebase'."

February 27, 2014JD Rennison

Exercise: it's all about women

Personal trainer: so why do you want to exercise?
Me: To look good for women.
PT: Any other reasons?
Me: Absolutely none. It's all about the chicks.

And I'm doing this just in case I up my odds with them a little bit. It's not hard to improve from zero you think? Well, it damn well is for me.

Any other reason to exercise, keep healthy for example, is but a by-product. Keeping healthy = living longer if you don't get terminally ill or have an accident. Just think though: you'll be working until you're 65. The average lifespan of a man is 74 years. That means you'll have busted your arse all your life so you can get a shit pension for the last nine years of your life unless you're on a private annuity program.

Oh there is that too.

Other joyful things that you could come your way during your short stay in this life: muggings, being made redundant at 45, cancer and let's not forget that after the trade centres were hit we have woken up to the reality of terrorism and for five years we have been living in an economic hell that probably won't end in our lifetimes.

Why would you want to do this alone?

I'm at an age where shit starts to break down in your body if you don't take care of it. Do I want to exercise to postpone the inevitable failure of various body parts? Only if I'm to spend most of the rest of my life with a companion.

February 21, 2014JD Rennison

Anderson over Twitter row: "Sorry I typed something somewhere"

A Starfleet officer who yesterday came under fire for referring to a sentient android as "it" on Twitter, has issued a public apology.

Commander (Op-Spec) David Anderson said he should have "thought twice" before posting his tweet.

"I generally censor myself before I tweet something but it seems that people these days get self righteous over the most insignificant shit."

"Will a grovelling apology save me from a dishonourable discharge and my name from being smeared more than it already is? If so, I'm sorry alright? I'm sorry I posted this on the internet."
